From a safety perspective, raw milk is not inherently dangerous. The idea that raw milk is unsafe is a misconception rooted in outdated fears and flawed public health messaging. In fact, raw milk is produced under strict hygienic conditions on responsible, small-scale farms that prioritize animal welfare and clean environments. These farms understand that when a cow is healthy, the milk is healthy. When it comes to health benefits, raw milk retains all its natural enzymes like lactase, lipase, and phosphatase, which aid in digestion, fat absorption, and mineral utilization. These enzymes are destroyed during pasteurization. Raw milk also contains beneficial bacteria—probiotics—that support gut health and a strong immune system. In fact, some studies have shown that children who drink raw milk from local farms have significantly lower rates of asthma, allergies, and eczema. That’s not a coincidence; it’s the power of natural, living food.

It’s more difficult to digest, especially for people who are lactose intolerant, because the natural lactase enzyme is destroyed during pasteurization. That’s why we now have to add enzymes back in later—processing a natural food into something artificial just to make it palatable again.

So when we talk about safety and health, raw milk is not only safer when sourced responsibly, but it’s also more nutritious and beneficial for the body. It’s a whole food, not a processed product. Let’s stop fearing raw milk and start embracing its natural goodness.
